title: AI Governance Capacity
text:
This project analyses 2,216 AI policy documents from 193 countries, drawn from the OECD.AI Policy Observatory, to answer a straightforward question:

Do countries have the capacity to implement their AI policies, and how does this vary between high-income and developing countries?

Three complementary lenses â€” implementation capacity, ethics governance depth, and UNESCO alignment â€” are used to trace how AI governance performs from the abstract (values) to the concrete (policy actions). The central finding is that ethical principles are widely endorsed but rarely operationalised: accountability mechanisms are the most systematically omitted governance feature worldwide.
All work is in progress. Comments and feedback are welcome.

title: Global Observatory of AI Governance Capacity
text:
This research infrastructure systematically measures and compares AI governance capacity across 2,200+ jurisdictions worldwide, using the OECD.AI Policy Observatory corpus. The project addresses a central question:

Do countries have the capacity to implement their AI policies, and how does this vary between high-income and developing countries?

The analysis employs three complementary lenses â€” implementation capacity, ethics governance depth, and UNESCO alignment â€” to map the global landscape of AI governance from the abstract (values) to the concrete (policy actions). The findings reveal a consistent pattern: ethical principles are widely endorsed but rarely operationalised, with accountability mechanisms the most systematically omitted governance feature worldwide.
